I think it is slowly dawning on corporations that they need consumers to sell things to, to be successful. Could be, in the final analysis, that some redistribution has to occur so they have customers who will buy their products, increase profits so they can be re-redistributed, thus completing the circle. There is ideology and reality. One always eventually wins.

"I think it is slowly dawning on corporations that they need consumers to sell things to"

There is zero interest in or understanding of the larger world or of any aspect of public policy among big business types at any level within a company, notably among top executives.

In addition however, that is really not their concern under the rules of the game, so to speak.

Thus while easy to ridicule many big company executives and usually warranted to do so, concern about the wider world except as it impinges directly on an executive doing his or her job that is never relevant nor of any interest.

What if..... in the future a viable economy could consist of capitalists only? Of course, there would not be that many humans involved (let's say 5% of the population), but nevertheless, huge sums of money would circulate, but only, say, between corporations - one corporation's spending being another corporation's income. Just as in the current economy, my spending is your income. After all, corporations are "persons", so why so far fetched.? Conceivably huge wealth accumulation could proceed apace such that healthy GDP growth is maintained.

Of course, this means that the actual population (the non-capitalists; the 95%) is economically irrelevant except to the extent that its insistence on eating (mooching in the derisive capitalist vernacular) is of negative value in this model.

What to do in that case? Not really an economics problem as the 95% have been clamped off and dissected out of the economy. Certainly a political problem (lots of hope there?). Ultimately a moral problem. Ironic....... this actually might be a morality play.

And, if you are subject to a gloomy distopian view of the future, you have to keep in mind that the ideal (from the corporation's point of view) number of employees per corporation is one: the owner. But, corporations are people, so maybe the ideal number is zero. The real nightmare is waking up to realize that the machine takeover in science fiction is really the corporations.

" It is astounding to me that the rise in Christian rhethoric in politics is directly proportional to the rise in policies that undermine Christ's teachings."

Well-said, Kevin, well-said.
I am a Christian, of the old-school progressive "social gospel" type and I thank God that Senator Kay Hagan had the political street smarts to play her Jesus card correctly. She's one of the few anchors keeping North Carolina from drifting completely into the backwaters. I'm sad that so much of the country's emotional landscape now resembles that of the deep South.

I am an atheist, but I was raised in a religion in which I learned the teachings of Jesus Christ.  It is astounding to me that the rise in Christian rhethoric in politics is directly proportional to the rise in policies that undermine Christ's teachings. The men and women who fight against food stamps,  unemployment benefits, health care for the poor and  a livable minimum wage, are the same men and women who falsely claim that they follow Christ's teachings.  I shouldn't be surprised.  These are the sons and daughters and grandchildren of people who held aloft the bible as they enslaved and lynched and segregated people because of the color of their skin.  These people don't want their long track record of immorality read back to them.  But we know their track record.    And their latest ideas -- that we as Americans have no basic right to health care, a living wage, or food in our innocent children's mouths -- is as immoral and wrong as the past ugly beliefs these people's grandparents were willing to kill our grandparents over.  For decades we as a country had been moving in the right direction, bending towards justice.  No more.

I design and run physics simulations on supercomputers for a living. A bit too applied and thus beneath a Computer Scientist/futurist, I know. I see things differently ...

Lets not imagine stopping the computers -- and just imagine going back to the non-computerized version which is the common sense version of your thought experiment. For example, I was unable to find a non-computerized toaster recently. Now I have a quirky, breakable piece of electronics replacing my durable 20-year-old electric (not electronic!) toaster. Computerized cars are marginally more efficient for the cost being more expensive to make and almost impossible to repair. Electronics are toxic waste and hard to recycle. If you include the total cost of electronic versions (including disposal) I doubt we are looking at much gain. Even worse, most individual use of computers is for entertainment. Fun maybe but economically worthless or even negative. Kids today are addicted to their phones, barely exercise and have short attention spans. Your example of farming beggars belief. I am sure farmers can cope without a "complex algorithm" to turn on a hose.

I see few gains from computers past the 90's -- email and the spreadsheet program and that's about it. If computers went away, we'd be "plunged" back into the 1960's with better health care. The horror. Maybe I could get real service in a store or talk to a person on the phone again. We'd have to cope with full employment too.

"have long been abandoned by too many of us."

I have to agree with this. Starting with St. Ronald, the ideas that made our country great - education for everyone, strong unions, integrity in government, the obligation of the wealthy to shoulder their share of the heavy lifting, caring for the people who couldn't care for themselves, equality of all groups in society, and many similar attitudes - were finally overcome by the people who brought us the Great Depression and who have been fighting against FDR's New Deal. These values were abandoned by a whole party and a significant percentage of the other party.

That abandonment has been responsible for the rise in poverty, the stagnation of income for the vast majority while the elites have seen their incomes increase by over 300%, the return of Jim Crow, the cessation of socioeconomic mobility, increasing injustice, social unrest, and more. Thanks a lot, those of you who buy into the right wing anti populism, for destroying my country. Maybe you're working on the theory that in order to improve, we have to start from square one.

Jimmy Carter has never foisted his faith on anyone. He's always championed freedom of religion and freedom from religion, equally. He's always been a champion of women's rights, including reproductive rights. He's never held adherence to the religious beliefs he holds and lives by, as a condition for doing anything on behalf of his fellow man.

One might take or leave some of his political views, but when it comes to honesty, principles, and fairness, few rise to Jimmy Carter's standard.

Rima, you missed my point. I was not critiquing Carter's political policies/beliefs (nor Nixon's, Reagan's, Clinton's or Obama's). My point is that Carter talked way too much [in my opinion] about his Southern Baptist evangelical feelings and experiences, and so made religion much more acceptable a part of White House life and overall governance - where it does NOT belong. The point is not whether or not he foisted anything on anyone - the point was that by his comments and actions, he weakened the separation of church [any church, every church] and state.

Sorry, Jason, but I know Jimmy Carter, and he and Rosalyn are the real deal. That's why right-wingers hated him, and preferred the pretend sanctimony of Ronald Reagan. It's often said that if Jesus were preaching among us today he'd be killed a lot sooner than he was back then, and I think that's true.

In my opinion, this absurd obsession with religion as a true barometer of one's political credentials began in modern times when Richard Nixon cynically brought Billy Graham into the White House as an advisor or spiritual consultant or whatever he was supposed to be. It continued with the overly sanctimonious Jimmy Carter blathering about his "born again-ism" and then exploded under Ronald Reagan when the Christian right became a major political and policy-making force. Neither Clinton, Bush II, nor even Obama has seriously attempted to curtail government-funded, faith-based nonsense, and the present Supreme Court, controlled by conservative Catholics has mad a mockery of the separation of church and state. Religion fundamentally appeals to the irrational, the illogical, and the emotional - precisely the opposite of what is necessary to govern a disparate and diverse nation of 320 million people.

To allow this kind of deficient thinking to have a dominant affect on our government can spell disaster in the future.  Bible quoting so called christian people inject more HATE about people than I have witnessed since the civil rights movement. The GOP only exploits what is a deep seated emotion in people and says its God. Better than saying the devil made me do it.

What has religion, valiantly trumpeted, done for this country over the past decade or so? With the rigged election of George W Bush, who wouldn't listen to Pappy but did find comfort in the teachings of an obscure 19th century Christian preacher, this country commenced to committing unconscionable and profoundly un-Christian acts. And many of these tactics for control have continued with president Obama.

Jesus railed against hypocrisy, describing the religious elite of his day as 'whitened sepulchres' and the money changers at the temple as an abomination. What Jesus stood for was compassion for all, to live by the Golden Rule, to treat others as we ourselves wish to be treated, to not be greedy but to be kind.

Today's government, though its various leaders proclaim themselves Christian, have approved of pre-emptive wars, causing the deaths of thousands, assassinations by remotely controlled drones, torture, lying to our own citizens and other governments about our invasive surveillance by the NSA.

What good is any religion if it does not bring peace, harmony and non violence to a society, to a people. Many talk 'a good game' but if not truly Christian in heart and in act, not truly Christian at all.
